content.webTitle: Keighley girl lied about pregnancy and abortion to police, court told

fields.headline: Keighley girl lied about pregnancy and abortion to police, court told
fields.bodyText: A girl at the centre of an alleged sex grooming ring in West Yorkshire lied to police about becoming pregnant and having an abortion, a court has heard. The girl, who cannot be named, accuses 15 men of sexually abusing her when she was 13 and 14 during a 13-month ordeal. Fourteen of the men, aged 17 to 62, are on trial at Bradford crown court. They deny a total of 28 charges between them. The jury on Wednesday was shown a police video interview of the girl filmed shortly after she was taken into care in June 2012. She detailed how the alleged abuse began when she befriended a young drug dealer called Arif Choudry, who effectively pimped her out to his friends in Keighley, West Yorkshire. The men, she claimed, raped her at various deserted locations, including in an underground car park, in parks, and behind a library and leisure centre. Choudry is not on trial, but she accuses him of raping her behind a church in Keighley after she tried to stop helping with his drug deals. She was 13, he was 15. For a period of months leading up to the alleged rape on 4 May 2011, she had been delivering drugs for him instead of going to school, she told a detective, listing marijuana, steroids, ecstasy, heroin, cocaine and mephedrone among the drugs she would deliver “on a daily basis”. She insisted she never took drugs herself, but did it as a favour to Choudry, whom she described as a habitual cocaine and cannabis user. Choudry, the court heard, did not attend a mainstream school but was at a pupil referral unit for children with behavioural problems. On the video, she told police that when she tried to stop working for Choudry, he called her a “little white slag” and a “little white bastard”. He then pinned her to the ground and raped her, she said. “I felt like crap, basically. Like shit. Because I’m thinking I’m doing him a favour, when really he’s used and abused me,” said the girl. She then described how she ran home to her great-grandma’s house, where police were called. She admitted lying to officers initially, saying she had been raped by “two white males” and then retracted the allegation before she was supposed to undergo a medical examination, saying she didn’t want everything to “escalate”. She also admitted lying about having an abortion in hospital afterwards, explaining her lies by saying: “I was so pissed off as to what had actually happened I wanted to make it bigger than it actually was.” The girl confessed on video to a further lie, having told police that she had withdrawn £160-£180 from her grandma’s house under threat from Choudry. After her grandma reported the theft, the girl insisted Choudry had made her do it, threatening to “get” her sister if she didn’t comply. But that wasn’t true, she admitted to a detective in an interview filmed in October 2014. She didn’t want to go into details, she said: “I got myself wrapped up into a situation, but I don’t want to talk about it at the moment.” The girl, who is now 18, only disclosed that Choudry had been her first rapist when she was taken into care and told police he was just the first of a string of men to rape her – most of whom were introduced to her by Choudry. In another video the court heard how the girl had been made the subject of a police protection order on 15 May 2012, two weeks before she was taken into care. The case continues.
